remain objective when Analysing
our spending patterns.


My allergies are the sentinels
Of many buying sprees. Regard
less of the wonders Of certain
cleaners. detergents or facial
preparations, l am unable to use
them because of irritants.


Once ! succumbed to the sooth-
ing idea Of sleeping on satiy.
smooth drip dry sheets. We
bought four and the very first
time we put pair on our bed
| really woke up-wth an itch.
was a mass of wea1s. My poor
husband was staggering sleepily
while | changed to the plain
percale ones.


Armed with consumer guide
and an unf1inching armor against
advertising psychology 1--WE have
oought just as many things as
we've wanted-but how can we
tell If we truly wanted them
or we were just happy victims
OF that old devil advertising.


LINES TO AID HATERS
CLOTHES come cleaner with Fab,


Whisk or Duz,
Eds Sunbeam whites his beard


to fuzz.


Our dishes sparkle thanks to Lux,


Joy or Calgon.
My Teeth glisten from leem, not


Crest,


SO stop all the chatter, banter and


buzz,


Those darn ads can be all wrong
Something's they tout are better


than the rest.
You We tried most--now 60 out


and buy the best.

reached the U S. Supreme Court.

only about hundred get there Most others end

that the highest need hear only exceptional Besides
in trials the parties dispuing facts law

Statistics prove about so per-
cent of the entire population
suffers some sort of respiratory
ailment between September and
April of each year. No drug will
cure flu or the more than 100
varieties of colds! These con-
tagious diseases are caused by
viruses passed from person to
person. In an effort to reduce all
ments Americans suffer each
year, the Sentry Safety Council
of Sentry Insurance companies
has compiled these health tips:
. Avoid people with colds or flu.
Wash hands often, always be-


fore eating. Teach children to


keep fingers out of mouth.
Don't cheat on sleep.


. Eat well-balanced meals.


Drink plenty of liquids to tone


up system, help elimination.
. Guard against getting chilled.
. Exercise sensibly. Don't over


do shoveling snow, or in a gym.
. When you have a cold, stay


home and rest the first day.
Always cover your mouth


when sneezing or coughing. A


sneeze can blast thousands Of


germ-laden droplets IL feet.
. Use disposable tissues and


place in waste containers.


. Blow your nose lightly warns


the Sentry Safety Council.


Forcing spreads infection.
. Soap is an effective germ killer.


Keep your home clean.


. Don't rely solely on home reme-
dies. Indiscriminate use of


drugs can hide early warning


signals of serious illness. As


pirin and approved nose drops


give relief. Call your doctor If


fever, chills or headache per-


sists more than "a hours.


Finally, the Sentry Safety
Council says be thoughtful OF
others by keeping your germs to
yourself and you will guard your
own health :. F.. thoughtfulness is
contagious, too!

During the clark ages" ladies
used perfume to cover up odors
due to lack of adequate bathing
facilities. But today, perfume
should be applied after soapsuds
= in order to achieve it's full
potential of glamour.

At a time u}acn the death rate caused bv
automobile accidents is increasing o,td 0cci-
dent injuries haze nearly doubled since last
yeaY--the Arizona State LegiS latuYe is faced
with an attempt to REPEAL the state motor ve-
hicle iusbe ction law.


Opponents Of the bill haze raised their
UOices about needless repair bills or high in
sbection fees. They are trying to alarm the
citizens and min a REPEAL Of the biH


Arizona needs q motor Uehicle insbe ctiOn
lasO. In fact, the LAM should be made stronger
to include more inclusive inSbe ctiOn. No
harm can hardly come from any type of in
creased safety measures mben human lives
are at stake.


Why don't the opponents Of the bin check
with motorists whose automobiles WeYe in
bected and found to haze defe ctiUe brakes,
signal lights or some other defect. Some may
haze gYunabled about the repaid bill, but the
majority probably believe the dollars spent
we're worth 1t.


Isn't q life worth the cost Of the motor De-
htcle insbe ction? Remember the automobile
you haze insbe cted may be the one which is
safe enough for you to drive.

CONGRATULATIONS TO WILLIAM REILLY


William P Reilly. president state largest
firms Arizona Public Service the

the who selected him. Each year
ballots and each feel that the choices excellent

his feowman.

son he has ably headed the group through stages

in the who always schedules give

Congratulations Mr.. Reilly you

vIEws,p REvIEws
ANO REVIEWS


Edward Banks

doctorates' degrees are immune
from the long finger Of adver-
Using. Clustered in sterile and
remote labyrinths ofbooks. these
readers have found the last ref
uge from men and women who
now control many thought pro-
cesses Of humanity under the
guise Of advertising.


No one Is sure who started the
idea Of advertising. Ancient men
spent such of their time hunting
and fishing while the little wom-
en- labored in cave dwellings and
outside to make sure the homes
were happy. No doubt one hir-
suite hero jabbered about the cul-
mary skill of his favorite wife
who had made a delicious dino
saur meat pie. Maybe this was
the simple beginning Of the first
restaurant specializing In home
cooked meals.


Early man had few ways Of
communication. We retrace the
fragments unearthed by archae-
ologists. crude drawings on cave
walls. show US that early men
whether sub-human or not, were
endowed with artistic abilities.
Perhaps, some Of them travelled
about the territory decorating the
walls for others.


The great Sphinx in Egypt could
hardly be classified as a mere
statue to a mere man. 1t must
have been built to show the world
of the glories of the king or dy-
nasty in power at the time. Such
statues were rarely the spontan-
eous undertaking Of the lowly
worker or artisan. Some manhad
the wish to be known far and
wide.


Modern ingenuity has brought
us better mousetraps and even
better mice. Our lives are on
a higher plane than ancient cave
or cliff dwellers. but bas1cally
our emotions are on the same
level. After dinner we still en-
Joy Dragging about the biggest
fish, the biggest buck or the
highest bowling score. Husbands
still take pride in passing kind
remarks concerning their wives
cakes (even though Betty Croker
gave them hand).


Houses bear decorating
schemes of more established men
and women who don't paint ami
mails on the walls, although some
of their attempts resemble the
zoos.


No Sphinx has been built in
our era, but men of affluence
still make their indelible mark
in other ways. They finance
schools, theaters and hospitals.
while working to benefit mankind.


The advent Of newspapers and
magazines forced advertising to
become an integral part of our
lives. Radio and teleMsion en-
trenched advertising as one Of
the big businesses Of the world.


We live in buyers and sell
lers world. If you aren't selling
your pursestrings are open to
make a purchase. This inter-
change goes on constantly from
the cradle to the grave. A min
lister is hoping to win converts
to his particular fold.


A teacher hopes to sell the
apark of learning in the class
room. The architect designs one
magnificent structure in order to
win more fame and fortune. A
writer pens his best novel in
search of a reader or a place
on the top book list. A singer
cuts a disc hoping 1t will win
golden platter.

fen weeks ago another first sOas recorded
in Tucson, Arizona. Mrs. Jack (L0uya) Banks
maS selected as one Of the eight Outstanding
Women Of the Year by the Arizona Daily Star.
The fact Of her race is only incidental Mrs.
Banks sOus chosen not be cause she is q Negro.
She was chosen on the merits of her community
contributions and CHIC activities.


Mrs. Banks is also the Tucson National As
s0ciati0n for the Advancement Of Coloyed Peo-
pie choice for Woman Of the Year.


She is not q n0vice in the list of tIystS. Mrs.
Banks is the pre- sident Of the Tucson Young
Women'S Christian Association. She WaS the
first Negro in the WV me- stern region to be
elected to the presidency. She has been actiUe
in the WV organization since 1885.


A ,aative of Tucson, she has taught in the
public schools since 1913. In addition to all Of
her community activities, Mrs. Banks also
assists her husband with his re StauYant bus
mess.


The Arizona Tribune joins with the citizens
Of Tucson in extending ks4dos to Mrs. Laura
Banks. She wears her lQuYeIS Weu
